Award.AwardTitle: Women Achieving Tenure-Track Success: Strategies to Enable Community-based Retention

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Washington, North Carolina State University, and California Polytechnic State Institute, San Luis Obispo submitted an ADVANCE PLAN D project whose overall goal is to increase the retention and advancement of women in academic careers to create greater diversity in engineering leadership. This project will build and facilitate a community-centric mentoring, networking, and career development program and will target early career women in electrical engineering and underrepresented minority women in engineering and computer science. The early career women (postdoctoral and early-career faculty stage) will be supported through cross-career stage networking, community building, career development symposia, and peer Mentoring Circles.

The project adapts two previously successful efforts at the University of Washington: 1) Women Evolving the Biological Sciences (WEBS): professional development symposia for early-career women in ecology and evolution and 2) Broadening the Representation of Academic Investigators in NeuroScience (BRAINS): symposia followed by Mentoring Circles for early career underrepresented minority neuroscientists. This project will examine how best to adapt these successful programs to two new disciplines and develop a model framework to allow others to develop such programs for a wide variety of fields and populations. To maximize program impact, the team will use ethnographic research methods to study the process and unique features of program development such as the collaboration between engineers and social scientists to develop new knowledge on the principles and processes critical to planning, implementing, and adapting successful intervention programs. The evaluation of the project will identify best practices to support women's success in academic careers and to diversify the engineering professoriate. The guiding principles and values that enable these programs to have impact on participants will be identified and codified in a framework that will be shared through the University of Washington's ADVANCE online "LEAD-it-Yourself!" toolkit.

The NSF ADVANCE Partnerships for Learning and Adaptation Networks (PLAN) program track supports projects that promote the adaptation and implementation of previously effective ADVANCE programs in new contexts and the testing of innovative strategies to promote the participation, success, and advancement of women in STEM academic careers. PLAN projects also contribute to the knowledge base on gender equity in STEM academic careers. The PLAN-D funding track is designed to expand the application of proven-successful gender-equity initiatives for STEM faculty in a specific disciplinary area through networked adaptation of a specific program or initiative. Careful evaluation is expected to expand understanding of such initiatives in a disciplinary context.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project created the LATTICE (Launching Academics on the Tenure Track: an Intentional Community in Engineering) Program. The overall project goal was to adapt, articulate, and disseminate an existing professional development model to support the persistence and advancement of underrepresented groups in engineering faculty careers. This project focused on women in electrical engineering and computer science for the first program and underrepresented minority women in engineering for the second program, hence contributing to broader impacts by diversifying engineering faculty ranks. 

 

Major project activities included professional development symposia for early-career women in engineering, peer mentoring circles for program participants, and social science research to study the professional development model itself, the model's adaptation to new STEM disciplines (e.g., engineering), and the program organizers. 

 

This project held two successful national symposia for early-career women in engineering who were pursuing or interested in pursuing faculty careers. The first national LATTICE symposium for early-career women in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science was held May 18-21, 2017. This first symposium included 30 early-career women participants who learned from each other and a collection of senior panelists who shared tips, tools, and experiences.   The second national LATTICE Symposium was for underrepresented minority women in engineering.  The second symposium was held  May 30 - June 2, 2019 and included  32 women in engineering from historically marginalized and underrepresented racial/ethnic groups. The 2019 symopsium included a dedicated session on gender and sexual harassment in STEM that was led by a trauma-informed expert psychologist who has experience with women of color in STEM fields. Following each symposium, participants were placed in peer mentoring circles for ongoing support and professional development. LATTICE II participants were also invited to participate in self-care circles with the same professional who led the 2019 symposium session on gender and sexual harassment. 

 

Evaluation data at the end of the grant demonstrate that LATTICE participants reported lasting impacts of the program. For LATTICE I participants, statistically significant improvements to research self-efficacy were sustained for over two years, suggesting the lasting impact of the LATTICE program. Evaluation data also indicated that LATTICE II participants received numerous positive impacts from the program. LATTICE II participants reported improvements in self-efficacy, mentoring and networking, level of satisfaction with their career progression, and sense of belonging. 

 

The intellectual merits of this project stem from the ethnographic research which deepens and extends theoretical considerations between the social study of scientific social movements, intersectionality, and participatory action research. The research was motivated by the following questions: 1) How do feminist ethnographers enact care in our relations with the worlds we study creating new knowledge within the bounds of counterspaces, while also maintaining accountability relations and methodological commitments to anonymity, friendship, care, and justice in the dissemination of this knowledge? 2) When the field site is a counterspace, how might an ethnographer theorize with and not about research participants, creating "polyvocality" while still accounting for racial, social, political, institutional and epistemic differences and the tensions resulting? 3) How can the LATTICE ethnography contribute insights into how sexual harassment is experienced in STEM across a range of intersectional standpoints and create new theories of why sexual harassment occurs within a context of particular cultural norms and values? This project made a methodological contribution to engineering and science studies in regards to qualitative data on highly-underrepresented group members. This work created new knowledge on how gender intersects with race, ethnicity, and academic discipline in collaborative efforts to broaden participation in science and engineering.


Last Modified: 12/07/2020
Modified by: Joyce Yen
